Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Collaborative Research: Assessing the Feasibility of Programming the Ambient Wireless Environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless connectivity has become an indispensable utility in everyday life. Far beyond providing basic communications, wireless infrastructure comprises the backbone of the control and management functions of many Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystems, ranging from smart home solutions to autonomous vehicles. Therefore, countless efforts have been made to ensure the efficiency and reliability of such critical infrastructure. Against this backdrop, this project follows the same overarching theme of improving wireless infrastructure towards faster and seamless connectivity. From a scientific perspective, the project seeks to investigate the feasibility of fundamentally transforming the technical approach to wireless network design by shifting the focus from the data networks themselves to the ambient environment. From an industrial perspective, the project opens the way for the contribution of techniques to both improve cellular network link quality and enable co-existence of Wi-Fi technologies in dense urban deployments, where interference limits their effectiveness. From an educational perspective, the project has the potential to change the way academia teaches the topic of wireless communications and the wireless channel to undergraduate students and graduate students alike.

The traditional approach to optimizing wireless networks revolves around the wireless endpoints, i.e., the transmitters and the receivers, and takes the wireless channel as a hard constraint, invoking a multitude of solutions to fully utilize that channel. This project will instead focus on whether it is feasible to optimize the ambient wireless environment. Instead of changing the ways in which endpoints behave, the project will explore ways of changing the perceived channel along the wireless link to create more favorable conditions for wireless communication. Specifically, the team will explore how to instrument the wireless environment with small wireless elements to effect changes in the wireless channel that a wireless receiver measures from a wireless sender. A substrate comprising these elements is then combined with a control infrastructure that measures the channels between wireless senders and receivers in real time, and actuates the element substrate in order to effect channel variations. As a proof of concept, the team will explore using this design to improve individual links as well as reduce interference between concurrent links.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless networks are indispensable today, providing ubiquitous connectivity coverage as well as comprising the backbone of many Internet-of-Things (IoT) ecosystems, ranging from smart home solutions to autonomous vehicles. Against this backdrop, this project follows the same overarching theme of improving wireless infrastructure towards faster and seamless connectivity. From a scientific perspective, the project has demonstrated the feasibility of fundamentally transforming wireless network design by shifting the focus from the data networks themselves to the ambient environment. We have explored three distinct ways of altering signal propagation behavior: phase alignment via massive wall-embedded antenna arrays, multi-hop amplification, and metamaterials-based polarization tuning via large surfaces. These approaches encompass ways that the environment can manipulate radio signals that are inaccessible to endpoints, such as rotating the polarization of a radio signal when it bounces off or transmits through a wall.

Our proof-of-concept systems include the following designs and experimental results. We have implemented and deployed a large, wall-embedded array in a real indoor home environment, the first prototype of its kind we are aware of. In particular, while communication endpoints have few means to counter "dead spots" due to multipath fading and spatial correlation for MIMO channels, our surface-based approach can eliminate or reduce both issues. Our results also show significant improvements in spectral efficiency, including significant improvements for networks that use multi-hop diversity/mesh techniques. Experiments in this setting show that by reconfiguring the wireless environment, we can achieve a 24% TCP throughput improvement on average and a median improvement of 51.4% in Shannon capacity over baseline single-antenna links, and a 25% improvement in Shannon capacity over a multi-hop diversity selection/mesh baseline. Over baseline multi-antenna links, LAIA achieves a Shannon capacity improvement of approximately 20%. We have also implemented and deployed a large metamaterials-based surface that mitigates polarization mismatch by rotating the polarization of 2.4 GHz radio transmissions that pass through or reflect off the surface. This metasurface, designed to augment Internet of Things (IoT) networks, is the first we are aware of that accomplishes polarization rotation in the crowded 2.4 GHz radio band. Our experimental prototype-based evaluation demonstrates gains in link power of up to 15 dB, and wireless capacity improvements of 100 and 180 Kbit/s/Hz in through-surface and surface-reflective scenarios, respectively, attributable to the polarization rotation properties of the metasurface. Further, we briefly experimented with human motion and activity detection sensing applications using metamaterials.

The above results have been widely disseminated in leading computer networking and communications venues, including USENIX NSDI '19 and '21, an invited "Research Highlight" contribution to the ACM SIGMOBILE GetMobile magazine, and an article in the IEEE Communications Magazine. Results were also disseminated in a series of invited seminars at University of Waterloo; Cambridge University; the Inria-Institut Mines-Telecom-Sorbonne Universite-Nokia Bell Labs Laboratory of Information, Networking, and Communication Sciences (Paris, France); Cosener's Multiservice Networks Workshop; a Rice University ECE Department Distinguished Speaker Series Colloquium; an invited seminar at the Samsung Innovation Forum; and an invited keynote at the New England Networks and Systems Workshop.

From an industrial perspective, the project has generated a few early prototypes of "smart surfaces" or "reconfigurable intelligent surfaces", which are of interest as they are on the roadmap for consideration for 6G, the forthcoming generation of wide area communication technologies. Our prototypes also suggest ways to consolidate infrastructure across a diverse set of wireless networking technologies, in a standards-agnostic approach.

From an educational perspective, the project has funded a Yale graduate student for one year as well as provided research opportunities for four Yale undergraduate students. The graduate student and two undergraduates come from Hispanic backgrounds.
